DOC.HEAD: Tit-for-Tat: Armored Cars Surround U.S. Embassy, Later Withdraw
Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with tanks withdrawn. Picks up 11th pvs, `Each vehicle...' EDITS thereafter to conform.
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government moved tanks and armored cars into positions outside the U.S. Embassy Thursday after U.S. soldiers surrounded the Nicaraguan Embassy in Panama, but later withdrew them without explanation. President Daniel Ortega said earlier Thursday that ``if the U.S. government withdraws the armored cars and troops that surround the Nicaraguan Embassy, then we will respond in the same way here.'' A curfew was in effect in Panama City and it was not immediately known if the U.S. troops left the Nicaraguan and Cuban missions. Associated Press photographers in Managua saw at least seven Soviet-made T-55 tanks, three armored personnel carriers and three trucks of anti-aircraft weapons leave the embassy between 9:30 and 10:30 p.m. (10:30 and 11:30 EST). Embassy spokesman Lou Falino said people at the embassy heard the noise of several engines ``but they could not determine if the tanks were withdrawn because it was dark.'' He was contacted at his home. American armored cars, part of a U.S. invading force, surrounded the Nicaraguan and Cuban embassies in Panama City Thursday after rumors spread that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was hiding in one of the two missions. ``We have ordered exactly that the same thing be done here, around the U.S. Embassy, as was done in Panama City,'' Foreign Minister Miguel D'Escoto told a news conference. He indicated he was holding the United States responsible for the safety of Nicaraguan diplomats in Panama. Reporters in Managua saw the Soviet-made T-55 tanks and armored carriers brought in Thursday afternoon and parked, partially hidden, behind the U.S. Embassy. Each vehicle was manned by a crew of six and armed with a machine gun and a light cannon. Col. Julio Ramos of the army general staff personally supervised the deployment shortly after midday. An AP photographer at the scene said at first the armored carriers were pointing their machine guns and cannon away from the embassy compound. But an officer ordered the crews to keep the weapons aimed at the mission. Asked for comment, Ramos said he was acting ``on higher orders, for reasons already explained by Foreign Minister D'Escoto.'' But an unidentified officer, interviewed live by state radio, said ``this is in response for what they are doing to us now in Panama.'' ``They have just surrounded our embassy in Panama, and they think we are going to remain here with our arms crossed?'' the officer added. D'Escoto told reporters Nicaragua has demanded ``the immediate withdrawal of the invading, imperialist U.S. military presence around our diplomatic mission in the independent and sovereign Republic of Panama.'' ``As soon as they dismantle their deployment there, we are going to do the same here _ so, we are going to wait until they become reasonable,'' D'Escoto added, calling the American encirclment of the embassies in Panama City ``an act of intimidation.'' He said there were women and children, as well as diplomats, inside the Nicaraguan Embassy in Panama. Soviet-made T-55 tanks, guns, mortars and antiaircraft cannon were in place all over Managua and in other strategic locations around the country early Wednesday, hours after American troops invaded Panama to oust and try to capture Noriega. The deposed strongman is wanted in the United States on drug-trafficking and money-laundering charges. Nicaraguan officials said the measures were taken in case the United States instigates military action against this country. For many years, Sandinista spokesmen have been saying the United States intends to invade Nicaragua. U.S. officials have persistenly denied this. Charge d'affaires John Leonard has been the senior diplomat here since Ambassador Richard Melton was expelled July 11, 1988, after the ruling leftist Sandinistas accused him of interfering in Nicaragua's internal affairs. Relations between the Sandinista government and the United States have been steadily deteriorating since 1980, about a year after the Sandinistas came to power, when they established military ties with Cuba and the Soviet Union.
